video.title: TEDTalks: The Capitalism Paradox
video.synopsis: As the world economy muddles through "the great recession," how will capitalism reinvent itself? TED speakers place their bets and discuss prosperity.

episodes.synopsis: Over the past centuries, Western cultures have been good at creating prosperity for themselves. Why?
episodes.title: Niall Ferguson: The Six Killer Apps of Prosperity

episodes.synopsis: Shashi Tharoor argues that the size of its army matters less than a country's ability to influence the world's hearts and minds.
episodes.title: Shashi Tharoor: Why Nations Should Pursue 'Soft' Power

episodes.synopsis: Jacqueline Novogratz presents stories of how "patient capital" can bring sustainable jobs, goods, services -- and dignity -- to the world's poorest.
episodes.title: Jacqueline Novogratz on Patient Capitalism

episodes.synopsis: A designer explains the often overlooked value of time off and shows the innovative projects inspired by his time in Bali.
episodes.title: Stefan Sagmeister: The Power of Time Off

episodes.synopsis: A psychologist argues that freedom of choice has made us not freer but more paralyzed, not happier but more dissatisfied.
episodes.title: Barry Schwartz on the Paradox of Choice

episodes.synopsis: A statistician measures a nation's success not by its productivity but by the happiness and well-being of its people.
episodes.title: Nic Marks: The Happy Planet Index

episodes.synopsis: Alain de Botton examines our ideas of success and failure -- and questions the assumptions underlying these two judgments.
episodes.title: Alain de Botton: A Kinder, Gentler Philosophy of Success

episodes.synopsis: Halla Tomasdottir explains how she took her company through the eye of the financial storm in Iceland by applying five "feminine" values.
episodes.title: Halla Tomasdottir: A Feminine Response to Iceland's Financial Crash

episodes.synopsis: A journalist argues that our societies have become addicted to extreme risk in finding new energy and new financial instruments.
episodes.title: Naomi Klein: Addicted to Risk

episodes.synopsis: An author shows how the engine of human progress has been powered by the meeting and mating of ideas to make new ideas.
episodes.title: Matt Ridley: When Ideas Have Sex

episodes.synopsis: One billion people are trapped in poor countries. How can we help them? An economist has a bold, compassionate plan.
episodes.title: Paul Collier on the Bottom Billion

episodes.synopsis: Can happiness be bought? An author sampled the world's most expensive products. His critique may surprise you.
episodes.title: Benjamin Wallace on the Price of Happiness

episodes.synopsis: Rachel Botsman says we're "wired to share" and shows how Web sites like Zipcar and Swaptree are changing the rules of human behavior.
episodes.title: Rachel Botsman: The Case for Collaborative Consumption

episodes.synopsis: When the dot-com bubble burst, hotelier Chip Conley went in search of a business model based on happiness. Here, he presents his findings.
episodes.title: Chip Conley: Measuring What Makes Life Worthwhile

episodes.synopsis: An economist asks, How do we in the West make sense of China and its phenomenal rise?
episodes.title: Martin Jacques: Understanding the Rise of China

episodes.synopsis: John Gerzema says there's an upside to the recent financial crisis -- the opportunity for positive change.
episodes.title: John Gerzema: The Post-Crisis Consumer

episodes.synopsis: How shall we protect workers' rights in industries where no single national body can keep workers safe and protected?
episodes.title: Auret van Heerden: Making Global Labor Fair
